Award.AwardTitle: Biological Consequences of Environmental Change in the Bivalve, Astarte: Relationships Between Lifespan, Growth Rate, and Cold vs. Warm Climate States
Award.AbstractNarration:
What are the biological consequences of environmental change? The goal of this research is to determine the impact of regional climate and geographic range size on the shell growth rate and lifespan of a common clam species from modern and fossil populations found along the southeastern US coastal plains and Mid-North Atlantic. The populations included in the study will provide an understanding of how environmental change will affect the lifespan of bivalves that live in regions with different annual temperature ranges. Outcomes will advance our knowledge of the effects of environmental change on organisms that live in sensitive coastal habitats. Our methods and results will have a significant educational benefit, especially for students from underrepresented groups (e.g., first-generation college students interested in STEM fields), and will be used by high school and undergraduate students by stimulating innovation using STEM educational mechanisms. Through the UNC-BEST (Baccalaureate Education in Science & Teaching) program, we will award future high-school earth science teachers the opportunity to perform scientific research that will generate authentic laboratory curricula for K-12 science courses. We will help teachers from Pender County Schools (which serves low income and disadvantaged households) to improve instruction by integrating writing with scientific discovery through the "Writing in Science and Science in Writing" program (a collaborative program with UNCW).

Astarte shells are uniquely suited to investigate links between environmental change and biological consequences (e.g., changes in lifespan and metabolic rate) because of their change in size and biogeographic distribution through time. We will focus on the abundant populations of Astarte in Plio-Pleistocene deposits along the US Mid-Atlantic and Gulf Coastal Plains and modern populations in the North Atlantic. The main objectives are to: 1) establish the seasonal timing of annual growth checks in different biogeographic populations of modern and fossil Astarte using isotope sclerochronology; 2) establish the relationship between biogeographic zone to growth rate and lifespan; and 3) establish the relationship of climate state to growth rate and lifespan. Objectives 2 and 3 employ the von Bertalanffy growth equation and its derivative (standard growth index; SGI) to compare shell growth of a population between modern and fossil, across biogeographic zones, and between cold vs. warm climates. Our null hypotheses will be tested using a mixed model ANOVA and PCA tests. These tests will determine the principal components controlling variability among Astarte populations. This study provides a greater understanding of how biogeographic distribution and differences in seasonal temperature range may influence bivalve growth and longevity and how changing conditions may affect future populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
What are the biological consequences of environmental change? The goal of this research is to determine the impact of regional climate (warm vs. cold: mid Pliocene vs. early Pleistocene, low vs. mid/high latitude) and geographic range size on the shell growth rate and lifespan of common clam species (Mercenaria mercenaria, M. campechiensis, and Astarte borealis) from modern and fossil populations. The populations included in the study will provide an understanding of how environmental change will affect the lifespan of bivalves that live in regions with different annual temperature ranges. We pursued the following objectives: (1) establish the seasonal timing of annual growth checks in different biogeographic populations of modern and fossil Astarte and Mercenaria species; (2) establish the relationship of biogeographic zone to growth rate and lifespan; and (3) establish the relationship of climate state to growth rate and lifespan. Outcomes will advance our knowledge of the effects of environmental change on organisms that live in sensitive coastal habitats.

Intellectual Merit

Related to Objective #1, we have one published paper and one manuscript in revision related to modern Astarte borealis from the White and Baltic Seas. Modern individuals of Astarte borealis from the Baltic Sea live for over 40 years (consistent with our findings from the White Sea; Moss et al., 2018) and grow slowly like many other high-latitude bivalve species (Moss et al., in revision). Seasonal growth checks coinciding with periods of slowed growth occur in Winter similar to other mid- to high-latitude species. Isotopic and growth analysis of Mercenaria spp. will be reported by Garrett Braniecki as part of his continuing master’s thesis.

 Related to Objectives #2 and #3, we have one published paper resulting from Kylie Palmer’s master’s thesis focusing on modern and fossil Mercenaria shells (Palmer et al, 2021). Her paper has implications for conservation paleobiology. An additional manuscript reporting on the 25-year oxygen isotope timeseries measured in a modern Baltic Sea A. borealis shell will focus on this species as a new environmental/climate archive. Modern FL Mercenaria shells are longer lived than modern NC shells, which may be capturing the pressure on the species by shell fisheries. Mid Pliocene shells are faster growing than both early Pleistocene and modern shells consistent with shells from warmer climates. Early Pleistocene shells are longer lived than mid Pliocene and modern shells. NC populations from all climate intervals have slower growth in comparison with FL populations. Preliminary isotopic data of fossil Mercenaria shells show summer growth cessation from Plio-Pleistocene localities in NC and FL. The duration of cessation is longer in FL shells than in NC shells. This pattern will be confirmed after all fossil  and modern individuals are analyzed isotopically and will be the subject of Garrett Braniecki’s master’s thesis.

In addition to these published papers and manuscripts in progress, results were presented at several professional conferences by the PI, undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral researcher totaling 10 individual abstracts.

 Broader Impacts

 The supported work provides, for the first time, a spatial and temporal relationship between lifespan and climate state/biogeographic province. Such a study is critical considering the environmental changes that are projected to take place within the next century and will contribute to the growing body of research in conservation paleobiology. The study covers a latitudinal gradient that will provide an understanding of how environmental change will affect the lifespan and growth rates of bivalves that live in regions with varying intensities of seasonality. The supported research integrates an international, multidisciplinary group of scientists from US, Germany, and Russian institutions. It provides a new paradigm for investigating biological consequences of environmental change.

The funded research provided valuable mentoring and training opportunities for upcoming young scientists. Postdoctoral researcher, Dr. David Moss, is a lead author on two papers. He will be a co-author on another manuscript reporting on the 25-yr oxygen isotope timeseries of A. borealis. He gained experience mentoring students in undergraduate research and in proposal writing. Dr. Lauren Graniero was supported as a postdoctoral researcher. She assisted in training students in laboratory methods and data interpretation. This opportunity allowed Dr. Graniero to gain valuable experience mentoring graduate and undergraduate research. Master’s student, Kylie Palmer, completed and published her thesis (Palmer et al., 2021). Kylie gained mentoring experiencing by helping guide and train undergraduate Sage Turek on her senior honor’s thesis. Sage completed her honor’s thesis in May 2021. Undergraduate Abby Fancher participated in image analysis of prepared shells Garrett Braniecki is a new master’s’ student who was supported as a research assistant. His master’s thesis research will build on Kylie Palmer’s research. The 25-year oxygen isotope timeseries recorded in an A. borealis shell was used by first-year PhD student, Hunter Hughes, in an advanced data analysis class for timeseries project. As a result, Hunter will be a co-author on a forthcoming manuscript.
